body: The work to do this should be pretty minimal and straight forward.  Remove `Clear-Host` as a function and reimplement as a C# cmdlet.
Can I take this one?
@dhulwells consider it yours!  If you have something basically working, you can always submit as a Work-In-Progress PR if you need help (just put `WIP:` as prefix to PR title)

@BrucePay it could be argued (and I expect the corefx team to argue) that [Console]::Clear() has the correct behavior from their point of view today which is terminal specific.  Personally, I prefer to have the scrollback buffer cleared as my typical use case is that I clear the screen so I can output a bunch of content and expect the buffer to only have the new content whereas retaining the buffer means I have to visually determine where the new content exists when I use my scroll wheel.  Having `-All` being no-op on Windows doesn't seem bad to me.

>  Personally, I prefer to have the scrollback buffer cleared as my typical use case is that I clear the screen so I can output a bunch of content and expect the buffer to only have the new content whereas retaining the buffer means I have to visually determine where the new content exists when I use my scroll wheel.

Amen to that.

So, from that perspective the best user experience would be to consistently clear the scrollback buffer too, on all platforms, as originally suggested in #8554.

Your decision was to rely on `[Console]::Clear()`, which, I would argue, shouldn't exhibit platform-specific behavior either (and perhaps should offer a parameter for opting into screen-only clearing).

So, yes, a CoreFx issue should be opened, but if the consensus is that _we_ want buffer clearing  on all platforms, we can certainly make that happen now without having to wait for `[Console]::Clear()` to be fixed.
I've opened a CoreFx issue: https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/issues/34463

@mklement0 I had to rollback the change from [Console]::Clear() back to $RawUI since [Console]::Clear() doesn't work remotely when there isn't a physical console (see https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/8609).

From https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/8609#issuecomment-452855146
>  there's interest to convert this to a C# cmdlet and extend it, so let's defer any enhancements to that effort
> it's implicitly part of #8606 since the way Clear-Host is currently implemented it's impossible to extend

Is there any reason why these changes wouldn't go into `ConsoleHost` instead of `Clear-Host`?  The host can decide what to do with the current `SetBufferContents` even if it doesn't *really* support the API.  For example, PSES will invoke `Console.Clear` if the args look like it came from `Clear-Host` but will no-op if it's passed anything else.

I realize that #8609 already changes back to using `$Host` for Windows, but is the expectation that custom hosts should replace `Clear-Host` for non-Windows?
@SeeminglyScience I think this would be in ConsoleHost. Feel free to push PR if you want.

@iSazonov All of the changes so far have made within the function `Clear-Host` itself instead of `ConsoleHost`.  There may be a very good reason for this that I'm not aware of, I'd just like to ensure that a custom host can still implement `Clear-Host` support on non-Windows platforms.
My understanding from PR discussion is that intention is (1) convert Clear-Host to binary cmdlet, (2) enhance rawui apis.

I'm not well-versed enough to have any opinion on the `Clear-Host` vs. `ConsoleHost` discussion, but I'm in favor of:
* Clear-Host respecting `Console.Clear()` (and subsequently, the terminal it's being run in)
* `Clear-Host -All` no-op'ing on Windows. Makes it easier for people to add it to their `$PSDefaultParameterValues`

@joeyaiello: 

The CoreFx team has agreed to fix `Console.Clear()` to clear the scrollback buffer too (see https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/issues/34463), where supported - which is pretty much everywhere these days -  which obviates the need for an `-All` switch.
The documented intent was always to clear the scrollback buffer too.

We can either wait for that fix or roll our own in the meantime.

I also can't comment on the `Clear-Host` vs. `ConsoleHost` discussion.

@PowerShell/powershell-committee reviewed this and agrees to have consistent behavior for `Clear-Host` across all platforms which is to have Unix behavior on Windows: only clear the screen, not the buffer.  Adding a `-All` to clear the buffer makes sense.  This is not considered a `Breaking Change` per the contract since it is interactive.

@SteveL-MSFT 

> to have Unix behavior on Windows

The Unix behavior is _accidental_, both in terms of `Console.Clear()` and the native `clear` utility (at least on Linux): the _intent_ has always been to clear the scrollback buffer too; only _technical_ reasons prevented that functionality.

As previously argued by you (and I concur), clearing the scrollback buffer too is the _expected_ and _most useful_ behavior.

Therefore, clearing the screen _only_ - if needed at all - should require _opt-in_, and not vice versa; thus, implementing something like a `-ScreenOnly` switch would make sense.

The advantages are:

* sensible default behavior, on all platforms

* no surprises to Windows PowerShell users

* variant functionality - if needed - available on an opt-in basis

---

If you're really intent on this departure from expected behavior, note that https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/8603 must be revised, given that a fix to `Console.Clear()` is coming.

@SteveL-MSFT 

>  Isn't your CoreFx change to add a parameter to allow clearing the scrollback buffer and not clearing it by default?

No, after some discussion, it isn't: the agreement is that clearing the scrollback buffer too was always the intent, so the fix will ensure just that - no additional variations in behavior will be introduced.

---

> if significant users wanted the scrollback buffer cleared, then we would have expected `clear` to have changed.

As for the intent: from `clear`'s  `man` page on Ubuntu:

> clear clears your screen if this is possible, including its scrollback buffer (if the extended “E3” capability is defined).  clear looks in the environment for the terminal type given by the environment variable TERM, and then in the terminfo database to determine how to clear the screen.

As for the practice: 

I'm reminded of the saying "Broken gets fixed, but shoddy lasts forever".
That is, users have probably found platform/terminal-emulator-specific workarounds to get the behavior they desire - yet, they'd probably prefer that `clear` do the right thing, _if they knew they could rely on it_.

---

> Clear-Host can't use [Console]::Clear() since it doesn't work over PowerShell remoting (unless it solely relied on VT100 and/or printing output...)

That's a separate issue, and I can't speak to that, but limitations due to remoting shouldn't dictate the default behavior for the typical, local case.

---

As for the meta issue:

> in the end we have to agree and move on.

Of course, and you always _do_, by virtue of your ultimate fiat power.

Conversely, if I feel that important issues haven't been addressed, I will attempt to point that out.

You're free to ignore that, but I wish you didn't, for the benefit of the community at large.

Of course, my objections may turn out to be misguided, but whether they are will only emerge in the course of a _discussion_. I recognize that deciding when it's time to stop is a subjective assessment, and you're free to do so anytime (and have decided to do so on several occasions).

On a personal level, however, I frequently find myself thinking that more discussion is needed and that when the fiat decisions are handed down they lack detail / aren't convincing to me personally.

@mklement0 PS-Committee decisions should not be taken as absolute.  If more data is available that we didn't have at the time of discussion, we welcome that and certainly can change/update decisions.  I don't imagine any work here will happen in time for 6.2 anyways, so let's revisit this once corefx has the change as that would set some precedent we could consider following.
Sounds good; thanks, @SteveL-MSFT.

In related CoreFX issue Core team agreed that Console.Clear() must be "clear scroll buffer". So we need wait the fix from .Net Core. Today I reread all about the problem and I agree with @mklement0 that modern expectations is to clear scroll buffer on Unix too.
While we wait CoreFX fix we could implement this in out RawUI API.
As for remoting we should open new issue and fix this using our RawUI API.
For remoting, the current architecture expects the RawUI API to be local to the client so it doesn't work remotely as there isn't a RawUI available on the remote system.

To add some context, there are a several [clear issues](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is:issue+label:integrated-terminal+cls+) reported in VS Code. A few of them are about scrollback not clearing as expected because of winpty issues. 

From reading the history, not clearing scrollback appears to be broken behavior in `libvte` that has persisted. Since the native `clear` is used, that behavior is respected which gives PowerShell the freedom to implement clear properly with scrollback cleared consistently.
